natural solution: We can use the coefficient of the $x^3$ term to find $b$. On the right we have $-14x^3$, and on the left, the only $x^3$ terms we will get when we expand are $-3x(ax^2)$ and $5x^2(bx)$.

So we must have $$-3ax^3 + 5bx^3 = -14x^3$$which means $$5b - 3a = -14$$To find $a$, we use the same reasoning and look at the $x^4$ terms. On the right we have $15x^4$, and on the left, the only $x^4$ term we will get when we expand is $5x^2(ax^2)$.
Then we know that $$5ax^4 = 15x^4$$which means that $a=3$. Then $5b -3(3) = -14$ and $b = \boxed{-1}$.
